channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Gates-Epstein ties expose philanthropy’s ‘hypocrisy,’ experts say
item.description: Is the scandal embroiling Bill Gates symptomatic of larger moral dilemmas in billionaire philanthropy?

item.title: Aid groups petition Israel high court to halt Gaza aid shutdown
item.description: Humanitarian organizations are warning that Israel’s registration rules threaten to hollow out Gaza’s humanitarian system, with dozens of NGOs facing expulsion by the start of next month.

item.title: When the next global health crisis strikes, will we be ready in 100 days?
item.description: Opinion: Right now, doubtful. Ensuring timely access to medical countermeasures will be key.

item.title: Water security failures risk hunger for billions. Countries must prepare
item.description: Opinion: Water scarcity doesn't just dry soil — it triggers hunger for billions. Here’s how governments can plan and implement policies that are future-fit.

item.title: Devex Dish: Winter is here for a post-USAID Afghanistan
item.description: Afghans are “desperate” as aid cuts bring mass hunger crisis in the winter months; why ending food aid to Afghanistan and Yemen threatens U.S. national security; and a look at the latest planned overhaul at the U.S. State Department.

item.title: Why Tenure Reform Is Key to Curbing Land Degradation
item.description: Máximo Torero is chief economist of the United Nations’ Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome

item.title: How two global development pros turned layoffs into consulting careers
item.description: Two consultants share tips for successfully pivoting to project- and client-based work.

item.title: Afghans ‘desperate’ as aid cuts bring mass hunger crisis
item.description: As the snow cuts off highland communities in Afghanistan, aid workers say many won’t be alive once it melts.

item.title: Devex Newswire: USAID exit leaves Colombia’s youth exposed
item.description: As gang violence fills the vacuum left by the shutdown of a USAID-funded youth resilience program in Quibdó, Colombia, we bring you the on-the-ground voices. Plus, The Global Fund’s country allocations get even more meager.

item.title: Organized crime and poor regulation to blame for toxic pollution threat
item.description: The lucrative, illegal trade and trafficking of waste products including many that are toxic could be set to surge across continents, thanks to patchy regulation, savvy criminal groups and corruption, UN experts said on Wednesday.

item.title: Central African Republic enters ‘decisive’ phase after landmark elections
item.description: Fresh from holding the most extensive elections in its history, the Central African Republic (CAR) is entering what the UN’s top envoy in the country describes as a “decisive period” in consolidating fragile peace gains, even as security challenges persist and disarmament efforts continue.

item.title: World News in Brief: Arab economies rise, rights experts call for police reform in India, Ukraine school closures, Myanmar airstrikes
item.description: A new UN report forecasts that the Arab region is seeing a gradual economic recovery despite continuing geopolitical uncertainties.

item.title: Over a billion fear losing land and homes within five years
item.description: Despite global progress in strengthening land tenure and governance, more than a billion people worldwide – nearly one in four adults – fear they could lose the rights to some or all of their land and housing within the next five years.

item.title: South Sudan: Funding gaps threaten nearly 2 million displaced people
item.description: Funding shortfalls are putting the lives of more than 1.9 million displaced people in South Sudan at risk amid rising humanitarian needs, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) said on Wednesday.

item.title: USAID moves out, gangs move in: The cost of aid cuts in Colombia
item.description: When U.S.-funded youth programs closed in Colombia’s Chocó province, they left behind a vacuum that gangs and armed groups were quick to exploit. Drawing on reporting from affected communities, The Aid Report traces the unraveling of years of prevention work.

item.title: Trachoma: What It Takes to Eliminate a Disease in the Pacific Islands
item.description: Two Pacific Island nations have been applauded for their successes in the global health campaign to eliminate the infectious eye disease, Trachoma. Better disease data, effective treatment campaigns and improved access to water and hygiene contributed to the major progress now being celebrated as 27 nations worldwide are declared Trachoma-free by the World Health Organization […]

item.title: Britain’s international aid cuts have failed. It’s time to change course
item.description: Opinion: A systematic analysis of the U.K.'s decision to slash its aid budget one year on shows that none of the original justifications for the cuts stand up to scrutiny.

item.title: Generative AI Could Deepen Inequality, Revenue Losses in Creative Industries
item.description: As generative artificial intelligence (AI) rapidly expands across nearly every sector of society, those that work in cultural and creative industries are expected to bear some of the greatest losses. With AI-generated content projected to dominate global markets in the coming years, combined with a lack of strong regulatory frameworks to protect intellectual property and […]

item.title: After a Brutal Winter, Millions of Ukrainians Face Deepening Displacement and Uncertainty
item.description: After surviving the harshest winter in a decade, millions of displaced Ukrainians are confronting a growing crisis marked by hardship and ongoing attacks as peace prospects remain distant. Inside Ukraine, repeated attacks on housing, energy systems and essential services throughout the winter left millions without heating or electricity for prolonged periods. While temperatures are slowly […]
